# The Financial Test Every Restaurant Owner Must Pass Before Expanding

* [Report this article](/uas/login?session_redirect=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.linkedin.com%2Fpulse%2Ffinancial-test-every-restaurant-owner-must-pass-before-uzd0c&trk=article-ssr-frontend-pulse_ellipsis-menu-semaphore-sign-in-redirect&guestReportContentType=PONCHO_ARTICLE&_f=guest-reporting)

[Accountific](https://ca.linkedin.com/company/accountific-co) 

### Accountific

#### We help food industry owners gain control over their finances and achieve better profitability

Published Jun 17, 2025

[+ Follow](https://www.linkedin.com/signup/cold-join?session_redirect=%2Fpulse%2Ffinancial-test-every-restaurant-owner-must-pass-before-uzd0c&trk=article-ssr-frontend-pulse_publisher-author-card)

The dream is powerful, isn't it? A second set of doors, a new neighbourhood buzzing with your brand's name, the ultimate validation of your hard work. It's the vision that drives every ambitious restaurateur.

But before you get swept away by that dream, let’s have a frank conversation about reality.

For a complete breakdown, check out the full article: [Think You’re Ready to Grow Your Restaurant? Pass This Financial Test First.](https://www.linkedin.com/redir/redirect?url=https%3A%2F%2Faccountific%2Eco%2Fblog%2Fthink-youre-ready-to-grow-your-restaurant-pass-this-financial-test-first%2F&urlhash=XG8O&trk=article-ssr-frontend-pulse_little-text-block)

Recent data paints a stark picture of the restaurant industry. Bankruptcies have surged, and an alarming number of restaurants are currently operating at a loss or just barely breaking even. This isn't just bad luck; it's often the predictable result of expanding on a shaky financial foundation.

This article is your financial litmus test. It’s not here to discourage your ambition—it’s here to make sure your growth is built to last. Pass these four tests, and you can move forward with the confidence that you're not just growing, you're building an empire.

### Pillar 1: Bulletproof Your Books & Master Your Cash Flow

Growing a restaurant on messy books is like adding a second story to a house with a cracked foundation. You must move from "shoebox accounting" to a real-time financial dashboard. This means meticulous daily records and clean financial statements (your P&L, Balance Sheet, and Cash Flow Statement).

The Most Dangerous Trap: The Profit vs. Cash Paradox

This is where so many expanding restaurants fail. Your P&L statement might show a healthy profit, but profit is not the same as cash in the bank.

You can be "profitable" on paper but unable to pay your suppliers, staff, or rent. Expansion is a massive cash drain (lease deposits, renovations, equipment) that happens immediately. Your new location likely won't be cash-flow positive for 3-5 years. Funding a massive, immediate cash spend with the feeling of profitability from your first location is a fatal error.

The critical takeaway is this: before considering expansion, you must have a non-negotiable cash reserve of 3 to 6 months of your current location's operating expenses. This isn't your expansion fund; it's your survival fund. This is what protects your core business from the inevitable cash crunch of opening a second spot.

### Pillar 2: Develop a Smart Capital Strategy

"Getting a loan" is an action, not a strategy. The source of your funding is as critical as the amount.

Here are your primary options in Canada:

* Retained Earnings (Self-Funding): The safest route, with no debt or loss of ownership. But it's also the slowest, and you could miss key market opportunities.
* Traditional Banks & The CSBFL: Big banks offer great rates but have strict requirements. The Canada Small Business Financing Loan (CSBFL) is a powerful, government-backed tool that can help, but you still need pristine financials and a strong operating history.
* Business Development Bank of Canada (BDC): Often called "the bank for Canadian entrepreneurs," the BDC is known for its flexibility. They offer options like interest-only periods at the start of a loan, which can be a lifesaver for a new location's cash flow.
* Private Investors: In exchange for equity (ownership), you get capital without debt. This is best for rapid, multi-unit growth plans but means giving up some control.

Ultimately, no matter which path you choose, every funder demands the same thing: clean, professional, and accurate financial documents. A well-organized financial package is what turns your ambition into a fundable opportunity.

### Pillar 3: Create the Growth Blueprint

"Winging it" is not a strategy. The success of your second location is determined by the financial model you build before you sign the lease.

1. Project Startup Costs (Honestly): A typical 40-seat restaurant in a Canadian city can cost $300,000 - $500,000+ to open. Your list must include everything from lease deposits and construction to equipment and licence fees. Crucial Tip: Add a 10-15% contingency fund. Expansion always costs more than you think.

2. Forecast Your Timeline to Profitability: Be realistic. Most new restaurants take 3 to 5 years to become consistently profitable. Don't fall for the "Replication Fallacy"—assuming your new spot will perform exactly like your first. Your revenue projections must be built from the ground up based on the new location's specific demographics, foot traffic, and competition.

3. Define Your Key Performance Indicators (KPIs): These are your vital signs. Relentlessly track:

* Prime Cost (Food + Labour): The #1 controllable expense. Keep it under 60% of sales.
* Break-Even Point: The exact sales you need to hit each month just to survive. This is your primary target.

A data-driven blueprint, stress-tested with "what-if" scenarios (e.g., What if sales are 20% lower? What if food costs jump?), is what transforms your plan from a hopeful guess into a resilient strategy for success.

### Pillar 4: Structure for Success

This is the most overlooked—and most critical—pillar. Getting your legal structure wrong can have irreversible consequences for your personal liability and your tax bill.

The Million-Dollar Mistake: One Corporation for Everything

Opening your second location under the same legal corporation as your first is a catastrophic risk. If the new location fails or faces a lawsuit, it can bring down your entire company, including your original, successful restaurant.

The Solution: Set up a separate legal corporation for each new location. This creates a liability shield, protecting the assets of your other locations.

This structure also has massive tax implications in Canada, impacting things like the Small Business Deduction (SBD) and your eligibility for the Lifetime Capital Gains Exemption (LCGE) when you eventually sell.

A smart, multi-entity structure doesn't just protect you; it provides critical strategic flexibility. This structure is what allows you to sell off an underperforming location, bring in location-specific investors, and create a path to a massively tax-efficient exit.

### Your Blueprint for Smart Growth

The dream of expansion is powerful, but in today's fierce restaurant market, hope is not a strategy. Success is about rigorous financial preparation.

Growing your restaurant is your passion. Managing the complex financial backend is our expertise.

At  [Accountific](https://ca.linkedin.com/company/accountific-co?trk=article-ssr-frontend-pulse_little-mention) , we specialize in the Canadian food and beverage industry. We handle your weekly bookkeeping, payroll, and tax compliance, giving you the real-time financial clarity you need to make smart, confident decisions. By partnering with us, you free yourself from financial overwhelm to focus on what you do best: creating incredible food and unforgettable guest experiences.

Let us be your strategic partner in turning your growth ambitions into a sustainable, profitable reality.

#RestaurantCanada #HospitalityIndustry #RestaurantOwner #SmallBusinessCanada #BusinessGrowth #FinancialManagement #RestaurantManagement

# How Restaurants Can Manage Cash Flow and Reduce Tax Liabilities in Canada

* [Report this article](/uas/login?session_redirect=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.linkedin.com%2Fpulse%2Fhow-restaurants-can-manage-cash-flow-reduce-tax-liabilities-85oje&trk=article-ssr-frontend-pulse_ellipsis-menu-semaphore-sign-in-redirect&guestReportContentType=PONCHO_ARTICLE&_f=guest-reporting)

[Accountor CPA](https://ca.linkedin.com/company/accountor-cpa) 

### Accountor CPA

#### The Financial Team you can Count on.

Published Feb 19, 2025

[+ Follow](https://www.linkedin.com/signup/cold-join?session_redirect=%2Fpulse%2Fhow-restaurants-can-manage-cash-flow-reduce-tax-liabilities-85oje&trk=article-ssr-frontend-pulse_publisher-author-card)

Running a restaurant in Canada involves juggling many financial responsibilities, from managing daily cash flow to ensuring tax compliance. With high overhead costs, seasonal fluctuations, and thin profit margins, restaurant owners must take proactive steps to maintain financial stability while minimizing tax liabilities.

This guide explores effective cash flow management strategies and tax-saving opportunities to help restaurant owners optimize their finances.

## The Importance of Cash Flow Management in Restaurants

Cash flow—the movement of money in and out of a business—is critical for any restaurant’s survival. Even profitable restaurants can struggle if cash flow is mismanaged. Common challenges include:

* High upfront costs for inventory and supplies
* Payroll and staffing expenses
* Seasonal fluctuations in revenue
* Unforeseen expenses, such as equipment repairs

By improving cash flow, restaurant owners can ensure they have enough working capital to cover expenses, invest in growth, and avoid financial stress.

### Strategies to Improve Cash Flow

Monitor and Forecast Cash Flow

* Track daily sales and expenses to identify trends.
* Use accounting software to forecast cash flow and prepare for slow periods.

Optimize Inventory Management

* Avoid overstocking perishable ingredients to reduce waste.
* Negotiate better payment terms with suppliers to ease cash flow constraints.

Control Labor Costs

* Use scheduling software to adjust staffing levels based on demand.
* Cross-train employees to improve efficiency and reduce overtime expenses.

Encourage Faster Customer Payments

* Offer incentives for early payments on catering or event bookings.
* Implement mobile payment options for quicker transactions.

Leverage Business Credit and Financing

* Consider a line of credit for short-term cash flow gaps.
* Use credit cards with cashback or rewards for business expenses.

## Tax Strategies to Reduce Liabilities for Restaurants

Proper tax planning can help restaurants reduce their taxable income and keep more money in the business.

### 1. Take Advantage of Tax Deductions

Restaurants can deduct many business expenses to lower their tax bill. Common deductions include:

* Food and beverage costs – Ingredients, packaging, and kitchen supplies.
* Rent and utilities – Lease payments, electricity, water, and internet.
* Employee wages and benefits – Salaries, health benefits, and payroll taxes.
* Marketing and advertising – Social media promotions, online ads, and printed menus.
* Business insurance – Liability, property, and employee coverage.

### 2. Claim Input Tax Credits (ITCs) on GST/HST

Restaurants that collect Goods and Services Tax (GST) or Harmonized Sales Tax (HST) can claim ITCs on eligible business expenses, reducing the net tax owed to the CRA. Ensure proper documentation is maintained for all tax-deductible purchases.

### 3. Use the Small Business Deduction (SBD)

Eligible restaurants operating as a Canadian-controlled private corporation (CCPC) can qualify for the Small Business Deduction, which reduces the federal corporate tax rate on the first $500,000 of active business income. This results in significant tax savings.

### 4. Depreciate Equipment and Assets

The Capital Cost Allowance (CCA) allows restaurants to deduct the cost of equipment, furniture, and renovations over time. Accelerated depreciation rules may allow larger deductions in the first year of purchase, freeing up cash flow.

### 5. Manage Payroll Taxes Efficiently

* Ensure compliance with Canada Pension Plan (CPP) and Employment Insurance (EI) contributions.
* Take advantage of the Small Business Hiring Credit, if available.
* Consider outsourcing payroll to avoid penalties for late remittances.

### 6. Plan for Seasonal Tax Implications

Restaurants with seasonal revenue fluctuations should plan their tax payments accordingly. Quarterly tax installment payments can help spread out the tax burden and prevent a large lump-sum payment at year-end.

### Conclusion

Successful restaurant owners in Canada need a strong financial strategy that balances daily cash flow management with long-term tax planning. By implementing these strategies, restaurants can reduce financial stress, optimize profitability, and ensure compliance with tax regulations.

Overview:
Restaurants Canada is a national, not-for-profit member-based trade association advancing the potential of Canada’s diverse and dynamic foodservice industry through member programs, research, advocacy, resources and events. Canada’s foodservice sector is a $100 billion industry that serves 22 million customers across the country every day. As the fourth-largest private-sector employer, Canadian foodservice directly employs 1.2 million people and indirectly supports another 290,000+ jobs in related industries, with $32 billion in food and beverage products purchased every year. www.restaurantscanada.org

# Restaurants Canada
The voice of foodservice | La voix des services alimentaires
Non-profit Organizations • Toronto, Ontario • 37,784 followers • 11-50 employees

## Overview
Restaurants Canada is a national, not-for-profit member-based trade association advancing the potential of Canada’s diverse and dynamic foodservice industry through member programs, research, advocacy, resources and events. Canada’s foodservice sector is a $100 billion industry that serves 22 million customers across the country every day. As the fourth-largest private-sector employer, Canadian foodservice directly employs 1.2 million people and indirectly supports another 290,000+ jobs in related industries, with $32 billion in food and beverage products purchased every year. www.restaurantscanada.org

## Posts
**Restaurants Canada** (1d): Yesterday we had the pleasure of enjoying a delicious Osmow’s staff lunch—an extended celebration to congratulate the team on the re-opening of their original Streetsville location, the very spot where the Osmow's journey began over 20 years ago. Cheers to many more years of success! 🎉 👏 [Likes: 26, Comments: 0]; **Restaurants Canada** (2d): Generations may differ, but they all matter. 51% of Millennials dine out weekly, compared to 35% of Boomers. Gen X spends the most at restaurants, and Gen Z is reshaping discovery through social media. Learn more and stay ahead — Start reading the 2025 Foodservice Facts report here: https://bit.ly/4nOzY0U #FoodserviceFacts2025 #Foodservice #Hospitality #data #consumertrends [Likes: 29, Comments: 0]; **Recipe Unlimited Corporation** (3d 4d Edited): We’re proud to share that our CEO, Frank Hennessey, has been honoured with a Lifetime Achievement Award at this year’s Rotman Alumni Awards. This recognition celebrates Frank’s remarkable leadership, vision, and impact on the Canadian restaurant industry and beyond. Throughout his career, Frank has not only guided Recipe through growth and transformation but has also inspired those around him with his commitment to people, innovation, and community. Congratulations, Frank, on this well-deserved honour! [Likes: 42, Comments: 0]; **Foodservice and Hospitality magazine** (3d): Mark von Schellwitz , Restaurants Canada ’s VP of Western Canada, has announced his retirement after more than 28 years with the organization. https://lnkd.in/gX9zey_F [Likes: 105, Comments: 85]; **Restaurants Canada** (3d): In this episode, we sit down with Chris Elliott , Chief Economist & Vice President, Research at Restaurants Canada, to unpack some of the biggest surprises from 2025: to explore the surprising 2025 sales rebound, how the GST holiday gave operators more than a breather, and why domestic tourism was the quiet hero keeping restaurants busy. Chris takes us behind the numbers—like why alcohol sales are slipping, why solo dining is on the rise, and how his POST strategy (Pricing, Operations, Staffing, Technology) can help operators tackle rising costs head-on. We also dig into the hot topics shaping menus and margins plus the real power of using data to make smarter moves. Most importantly, Chris shares why Foodservice Facts should be every operator’s secret weapon and gives us a peek into what’s ahead in 2026. Listen for: • Why sales are up—but profits aren’t • The hidden cost of ignoring productivity • What’s really changing on Canadian menus • How operators can use data to stay competitive 🎧 Tune in now on Spotify: https://bit.ly/42Yr9JV #MENUUnplugged #podcast #FoodserviceFacts #restaurants #data _____________________ 🎙️MENU Unplugged Podcast is a co-production of Restaurants Canada & Benchmark Sixty Restaurant Services 🎙️This episode sponsored by Groupex Canada [Likes: 4, Comments: 0]; **Restaurants Canada** (4d): Restaurants Canada's 2025 Foodservice Facts report found that 8 in 10 young Canadians have cut back on restaurant spending because of rising living costs. Western Canada VP, Mark von Schellwitz joined CTV Vancouver to talk about what government can do to help Canadians struggling with affordability. Watch the full interview here: https://bit.ly/46KcCCC [Likes: 12, Comments: 0]; **Restaurants Canada** (5d): It was a big week back in Ottawa for Restaurants Canada as we continued our conversations and lobby work around immigration, temporary foreign workers, removing GST from all food and strengthening the viability of the foodservice sector during this period of economic uncertainty. Our message is gaining traction—conversations with key decision-makers confirm they’re listening to our advocacy on affordability, workforce, and related issues. The response to our FOODISFOOD.CA campaign was very positive and gaining more interest. Additionally, we were able to share important context, real data and information on the use of temporary foreign workers. While this remains a complex issue for our sector, it’s essential we use these programs responsibly and continue to uphold the industry’s integrity and reputation. Read President & CEO, KELLY HIGGINSON 's full update here: https://bit.ly/42JsBje [Likes: 15, Comments: 1]; **Restaurants Canada** (1w): 🌍✈️Happy World Tourism Day! This year's theme, "Tourism and Sustainable Transformation," is a call to action for all of us. From coast to coast to coast, tourism is a powerful force that drives our economy, industry, celebrates our culture, and connects us with the world. Our vibrant food scene plays a massive role in this! Every time you dine at a local restaurant, you're not just enjoying a meal, you're supporting a network of local producers, farmers, fishers, and chefs. You're helping to sustain jobs and preserve the unique culinary traditions that define our diverse communities. 💡Fun Fact: The restaurant industry accounts for approximately one third of all tourism-related jobs—making it the largest employer within the tourism sector. #WorldTourismDay #SustainableTourism #ExploreCanada #SupportLocal [Likes: 11, Comments: 0]; **Restaurants Canada** (1w): Restaurants Canada is deeply concerned about the nationwide strike launched by the Canadian Union of Postal Workers as Canadians and businesses cannot afford continued disruption. Read our full statement here: https://bit.ly/4myFELp [Likes: 4, Comments: 0]; **Restaurants Canada** (1w): The Temporary Foreign Worker Program represents just 3% of the foodservice workforce, but it fills a critical need for rural, remote and tourism communities. Restaurants Canada's KELLY HIGGINSON joined CBC's Ontario Today to discuss the reality of the foodservice industry's workforce needs. Listen to the full episode here: https://bit.ly/46pSTJQ [Likes: 11, Comments: 1]

results.content: # The Top 10 Laws Governing Small Business Owners in Canada This article highlights the top 10 laws every small business owner in Canada should be aware of to navigate the regulatory landscape effectively. By staying informed about these top 10 laws, you can build a strong legal foundation for your business, avoid costly mistakes, and focus on growth. Business Registration and Licensing Laws The Canada Occupational Health and Safety Regulations apply to federally regulated businesses, while provincial guidelines govern most other businesses. Businesses must comply with Canada’s Personal Information Protection and Electronic Documents Act (PIPEDA), which governs the collection, use, and disclosure of personal information. Businesses selling goods or services to consumers must comply with federal and provincial consumer protection laws.
results.raw_content:
[Skip to main content](#main-content)






# The Top 10 Laws Governing Small Business Owners in Canada

[Paul Kidston MBA, ICD.D](https://ca.linkedin.com/in/paulkidston)

### Paul Kidston MBA, ICD.D

#### 🇨🇦 🇺🇦Senior Business & Government Advisor | Strategic Growth & Financial Management | Operational Efficiency | Sales & Market Expansion

[+ Follow](https://www.linkedin.com/signup/cold-join?session_redirect=%2Fpulse%2Ftop-10-laws-governing-small-business-owners-canada-paul-bncie&trk=article-ssr-frontend-pulse_publisher-author-card)

Starting and running a small business in Canada is an exciting journey, but it comes with a host of legal obligations. Understanding these laws is crucial for compliance and long-term success. This article highlights the top 10 laws every small business owner in Canada should be aware of to navigate the regulatory landscape effectively.

### Executive Summary

Running a small business in Canada is as rewarding as it is complex. By staying informed about these top 10 laws, you can build a strong legal foundation for your business, avoid costly mistakes, and focus on growth. Regularly consult with legal professionals and keep abreast of changes in legislation to ensure compliance in all aspects of your business operations



---



### 1. Business Registration and Licensing Laws

Every small business in Canada must be registered with the appropriate authorities. The type of registration—sole proprietorship, partnership, or incorporation—depends on the structure of your business. Each province has its own process, such as ServiceOntario for Ontario-based businesses or Service Alberta for Alberta. Additionally, some businesses require specific licenses or permits to operate, depending on the industry and location.



---



### 2. Taxation Laws

Tax compliance is a cornerstone of running a business in Canada. Small business owners must register for a business number (BN) through the Canada Revenue Agency (CRA). Depending on your revenue, you may also need to collect and remit Goods and Services Tax (GST) or Harmonized Sales Tax (HST). Familiarize yourself with income tax obligations, payroll taxes, and potential tax credits or deductions for small businesses.



---



### 3. Employment Laws

If you employ staff, understanding Canadian employment laws is non-negotiable. These laws cover minimum wage, overtime pay, vacation entitlement, statutory holidays, and termination procedures. Employment laws vary by province, so ensure you’re compliant with local regulations. For instance, Ontario’s Employment Standards Act (ESA) differs from British Columbia’s Employment Standards Act.



---



### 4. Health and Safety Regulations

All businesses must adhere to occupational health and safety regulations to ensure a safe working environment. The Canada Occupational Health and Safety Regulations apply to federally regulated businesses, while provincial guidelines govern most other businesses. Failing to meet these standards can lead to penalties and jeopardize employee well-being.



---



### 5. Privacy and Data Protection Laws

In today’s digital economy, protecting customer and employee data is paramount. Businesses must comply with Canada’s Personal Information Protection and Electronic Documents Act (PIPEDA), which governs the collection, use, and disclosure of personal information. If you operate within Quebec, you must also adhere to the newly amended Act Respecting the Protection of Personal Information in the Private Sector.



---



### 6. Consumer Protection Laws

Businesses selling goods or services to consumers must comply with federal and provincial consumer protection laws. These laws ensure that products are safe, advertising is truthful, and contracts are fair. For instance, the Competition Act prohibits deceptive marketing practices, while the Canadian Consumer Product Safety Act (CCPSA) enforces product safety standards.



---



### 7. Intellectual Property Laws

Protecting intellectual property (IP) is vital for small businesses that create unique products, services, or brands. The Canadian Intellectual Property Office (CIPO) oversees trademarks, copyrights, and patents. Registering your IP ensures exclusive rights and safeguards your business from infringement.



---



### 8. Environmental Laws

Businesses operating in industries with environmental impacts, such as manufacturing or construction, must comply with federal, provincial, and municipal environmental regulations. These laws address waste management, emissions, and conservation practices. For example, the Canadian Environmental Protection Act (CEPA) regulates substances that can harm the environment or human health.



---



### 9. Contracts and Commercial Law

Contracts are the backbone of business relationships, whether with clients, suppliers, or employees. Understanding contract law is crucial to drafting enforceable agreements. The Sale of Goods Act, applicable in most provinces, governs transactions involving the sale of goods. For more complex business arrangements, seeking legal counsel is advisable.



---



### 10. Bankruptcy and Insolvency Laws

While no entrepreneur starts a business expecting financial distress, understanding bankruptcy laws can be critical in challenging times. The Bankruptcy and Insolvency Act (BIA) provides a legal framework for restructuring or winding up a business. This law aims to balance the interests of creditors and debtors while offering relief for businesses seeking a fresh start.



---

results.raw_content:
# Canada's small business owners struggle with economic uncertainty

This title was summarized by AI from the post below.

[Sasha Boersma](https://ca.linkedin.com/in/sashaboersma?trk=public_post_feed-actor-name)

Co-Founder/Producer, Sticky Brain Studios | Board of Directors, Disability Screen Office | Women in Games Ambassador

* [Report this post](/uas/login?session_redirect=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.linkedin.com%2Fposts%2Fsashaboersma_your-industrys-small-business-owners-in-activity-7359321201506226176-JhdD&trk=public_post_ellipsis-menu-semaphore-sign-in-redirect&guestReportContentType=POST&_f=guest-reporting)

Your industry's small business owners in Canada are not doing ok. Look beyond the headlines of economic 'resilience' and talk to small business owners - Canada's in trouble. There is collective denial about the economic reality of entrepreneurship. Consumer spending is down. Austerity practices by those who have the money limits cash flow to consumers. Housing costs have a stranglehold on much of the population which impacts discretionary spending. Then trying to operate during global uncertainty with the bonus of investors (if your sector even has those) being cautious and pulling back... Unfortunately for us, it feels like Canada (including the provinces) is doing the typical thing going - if the big companies are ok, we'll be ok. On one hand, makes sense, in theory they will keep and generate the most jobs. But did anyone notice during the pandemic, how little money flowed out to employees from large companies? The volume of CEWS that then went into shareholder dividends instead of actual wages. The huge wage and bonus discrepancies between the executive class to their workforce. The mass layoffs that happened anyways? Small businesses employ close to 40% of Canadians. Small business leadership operates much closer to our employees and our customers. But now it feels like sustainable growth is impossible. We need new ideas. But we are all too tired of doing this ourselves to come up with those ideas. Colleagues who have reached out for help get financial lessons  when managing finances is not the problem. There is no shareholder value calculation that is going to inspire us out of the depression. It feels like, as a business owner, that we dont have any choice but to keep slogging through. It's not like we can quit our businesses and collect EI because we are not eligible for EI as a business owner. Maybe find another job? Unfortunately we see our peers struggling for employment right now. Many of us had a back-up through contract teaching at post-secondary institutions, but due to irresponsible government behaviours most of us have lost that too. Everyone else tells us how they are taking on the risk of our business for any number of reasons¦ but no one seems to want to recognize the risk small business owners take, and how we are left with nothing while large businesses with their investors keep floating along with increasing government support. The conventional advice is that we just need to business better. But we have businessed. We have businessed plans A, B, C, L, M, X, Y, Z and are now on plan AZ or 12M. Its the everything else going on around us that we cant control. The large entities that mislead us into bad business deals. The investors that say were too risky. The supply chain that has turned upside down. The increasing loss of consumer spending power. And the feeling that we cant talk about any of this, because social and economic systems are designed as though the small business owners are the failures.

[39](https://www.linkedin.com/signup/cold-join?session_redirect=https%3A%2F%2Fwww%2Elinkedin%2Ecom%2Fposts%2Fsashaboersma_your-industrys-small-business-owners-in-activity-7359321201506226176-JhdD&trk=public_post_social-actions-reactions)   [16 Comments](https://www.linkedin.com/signup/cold-join?session_redirect=https%3A%2F%2Fwww%2Elinkedin%2Ecom%2Fposts%2Fsashaboersma_your-industrys-small-business-owners-in-activity-7359321201506226176-JhdD&trk=public_post_social-actions-comments)

[Like](https://www.linkedin.com/signup/cold-join?session_redirect=https%3A%2F%2Fwww%2Elinkedin%2Ecom%2Fposts%2Fsashaboersma_your-industrys-small-business-owners-in-activity-7359321201506226176-JhdD&trk=public_post_like-cta)   [Comment](https://www.linkedin.com/signup/cold-join?session_redirect=https%3A%2F%2Fwww%2Elinkedin%2Ecom%2Fposts%2Fsashaboersma_your-industrys-small-business-owners-in-activity-7359321201506226176-JhdD&trk=public_post_comment-cta)

[Denis Coyne](https://ca.linkedin.com/in/denisjcoyne?trk=public_post_comment_actor-name)   1mo 

* [Report this comment](/uas/login?session_redirect=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.linkedin.com%2Fposts%2Fsashaboersma_your-industrys-small-business-owners-in-activity-7359321201506226176-JhdD&trk=public_post_comment_ellipsis-menu-semaphore-sign-in-redirect&guestReportContentType=COMMENT&_f=guest-reporting)

100%. Long story short, Ive recently navigated municipal bureaucracy around building permits. It was eye opening and infuriating. Im still traumatized. Its a real barrier to small business. I was trapped for 8 months. Thats measurable as % of my lifespan. I survived by the kindness of my skilled friends saving me tens of thousands¦ Rules and regs are importabt for safety, yes, but the systems weve built around them dont work. They punish people for trying to do it right. The people inside the systems are punished too. They avoid decisions because in that there is job safety. They dont help anyone unless its off the record, but there are barriers to even reaching them for direct communication. This isnt a system that benefits the economy. It definitely stifles small business. Now when I see a chain store on a corner I know why. They have more money, deeper pockets, and pay their way through it all via expensive consultants  or they just break rules and pay fines later. That shouldnt be the norm. We should be helping small business through. last time I checked the stats were clear, small businesses are a huge portion of the GDP.

[Like](https://www.linkedin.com/signup/cold-join?session_redirect=https%3A%2F%2Fwww%2Elinkedin%2Ecom%2Fposts%2Fsashaboersma_your-industrys-small-business-owners-in-activity-7359321201506226176-JhdD&trk=public_post_comment_like) [Reply](https://www.linkedin.com/signup/cold-join?session_redirect=https%3A%2F%2Fwww%2Elinkedin%2Ecom%2Fposts%2Fsashaboersma_your-industrys-small-business-owners-in-activity-7359321201506226176-JhdD&trk=public_post_comment_reply)  [4 Reactions](https://www.linkedin.com/signup/cold-join?session_redirect=https%3A%2F%2Fwww%2Elinkedin%2Ecom%2Fposts%2Fsashaboersma_your-industrys-small-business-owners-in-activity-7359321201506226176-JhdD&trk=public_post_comment_reactions)   5 Reactions

  Small business ambitions held back by economic uncertainty Only 17% of Australian small businesses plan to expand internationally, with new Xero research showing most owners are stopping short of global growth as confidence remains fragile. The survey of 500 entrepreneurs also found that while 83% believe Australia is a good place to start a business, fewer see the conditions to scale beyond domestic markets. That said, 48% of business owners already consider themselves successful, and another 48% believe they are on their way. But inhibitors remain, with 41% pointing to external factors such as economic conditions, 36% citing stagnant growth, and 27% highlighting access to funding as a barrier. These challenges show why many business owners hesitate to take the next step, whether thats expanding internationally or simply growing locally. Finance can play a key role in overcoming those hurdles, from improving cash flow to funding equipment or staff. With the right lending in place, however, small businesses can pursue growth on their own terms  and Lending Loop can help them secure the finance to get there. results.title: Canadian Small Business Owners Face Tough Times ...
results.content: 🇨🇦 \*\*investments\*\* Category : Business and Finance | Pays : Canada Here’s an SEO-optimized LinkedIn article for you: --- ## Unlock Your Canadian Financial Future: Smart Investing in 2024 In Canada's evolving economic landscape, smart investing isn't just for the wealthy – it's a critical strategy for everyone aiming for financial security and long-term growth. More troubling is research done by Hayden's firm showing that half of Canadian business founders who raised more than $1 million in equity capital in 2024 "were headquartered in the U.S." Canada needs a policy re-set to improve the domestic environment for entrepreneurial wealth creation and business growth.
results.raw_content:
# Merchant Growth’s Post

[Merchant Growth](https://ca.linkedin.com/company/merchant-growth?trk=public_post_feed-actor-name)

2,512 followers

* [Report this post](/uas/login?session_redirect=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.linkedin.com%2Fposts%2Fmerchant-growth_smallbusinessmonth-growwithmg-canadianbusiness-activity-7382149105122209792-V2xd&trk=public_post_ellipsis-menu-semaphore-sign-in-redirect&guestReportContentType=POST&_f=guest-reporting)

Canadian small business owners are fighting battles most people never see. 👉 87% have cut or delayed their own salaries, retirement, or major life plans just to keep their businesses alive. 👉 72% feel abandoned by government support. 👉 Inflation, tariffs, and slower spending are weighing heavily on their ability to grow. And yet, more than half say they’re more resilient now than before 2025. Yet that resilience comes at a cost. Behind every storefront or service is an entrepreneur making deeply personal sacrifices—selling assets, putting off retirement, even taking on second jobs—to keep serving their communities. At the same time, Canadians want to support them. 56% say they’ve consciously bought more local this year. But barriers like higher costs, limited availability, and fewer store locations still stand in the way. The message is clear: small businesses are doing their part. It’s time for the rest of us, including policymakers, partners, and consumers, to step up too. Because when small businesses thrive, Canada thrives. [#SmallBusinessMonth](https://www.linkedin.com/signup/cold-join?session_redirect=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.linkedin.com%2Ffeed%2Fhashtag%2Fsmallbusinessmonth&trk=public_post-text) [#GrowWithMG](https://www.linkedin.com/signup/cold-join?session_redirect=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.linkedin.com%2Ffeed%2Fhashtag%2Fgrowwithmg&trk=public_post-text) [#CanadianBusiness](https://www.linkedin.com/signup/cold-join?session_redirect=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.linkedin.com%2Ffeed%2Fhashtag%2Fcanadianbusiness&trk=public_post-text) [#Entrepreneurship](https://www.linkedin.com/signup/cold-join?session_redirect=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.linkedin.com%2Ffeed%2Fhashtag%2Fentrepreneurship&trk=public_post-text)



[Like](https://www.linkedin.com/signup/cold-join?session_redirect=https%3A%2F%2Fwww%2Elinkedin%2Ecom%2Fposts%2Fmerchant-growth_smallbusinessmonth-growwithmg-canadianbusiness-activity-7382149105122209792-V2xd&trk=public_post_like-cta)   [Comment](https://www.linkedin.com/signup/cold-join?session_redirect=https%3A%2F%2Fwww%2Elinkedin%2Ecom%2Fposts%2Fmerchant-growth_smallbusinessmonth-growwithmg-canadianbusiness-activity-7382149105122209792-V2xd&trk=public_post_comment-cta)

To view or add a comment, [sign in](https://www.linkedin.com/signup/cold-join?session_redirect=https%3A%2F%2Fwww%2Elinkedin%2Ecom%2Fposts%2Fmerchant-growth_smallbusinessmonth-growwithmg-canadianbusiness-activity-7382149105122209792-V2xd&trk=public_post_feed-cta-banner-cta)

## More Relevant Posts

* [James Jang](https://ca.linkedin.com/in/jamescjang?trk=public_post_feed-actor-name)

  Empowering Small Businesses with Tailored Financial Solutions | Advocate for Fair Lending Practices | Strategic Investor & Leader in Structured Finance

  + [Report this post](/uas/login?session_redirect=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.linkedin.com%2Fposts%2Fjamescjang_smallbusiness-entrepreneur-entrepreneurship-activity-7375876600917131265-faj9&trk=public_post_ellipsis-menu-semaphore-sign-in-redirect&guestReportContentType=POST&_f=guest-reporting)

  Canadian small businesses are not just facing headwinds They’re getting squeezed from both sides. [Equifax Canada](https://ca.linkedin.com/company/equifax-canada?trk=public_post-text) latest report shows over 286,000 businesses missed a credit payment last quarter Up 5.6% from last year. That’s not just a stat It’s a red flag. Think about what’s happening here: ⚡ Consumers are cutting back because groceries and rent eat first. ⚡ Trade disputes are making imports and exports more expensive. ⚡ And entrepreneurs are left absorbing the blows with less margin, less credit, and less time. This is not just about “delinquencies.” It’s about survival. You can’t run a restaurant, a retail shop, or a small service business on optimism when the math doesn’t work. Here’s the uncomfortable truth: Resilience doesn’t come from slogans. It comes from systems that don’t push small businesses to the edge every time the economy hiccups. We keep saying small business is the backbone of Canada’s economy. But how long can a backbone hold when it’s carrying everyone else’s weight Consumers, leaders, and global trade fights? The next six months will be defining. Not for big corporates They’ll weather it.   This post really hit me. I spend a lot of my time talking to business owners — people who are putting everything on the line to build something meaningful. They’re not just running a business; they’re creating jobs, supporting families, and fueling local communities. And yet, the reality is, they often have to do all of this while working against systems that weren’t really built for them. Whether it’s banking infrastructure, access to funding, or policy support, too many of the tools available are geared toward the few, not the many. That’s why I believe we need to start flipping the script. If 99.8% of businesses in Canada are SMBs, then the support, resources, and financial structures should reflect that. Imagine the growth, innovation, and stability our economy could see if entrepreneurs had the right foundation beneath them. I see the resilience and creativity in business owners every single day. It’s time the systems caught up to them.   RBC CEO Dave McKay is calling for Canada to shed its risk aversion if it wants to stay competitive in a rapidly changing global economy. Speaking at the Calgary Chamber of Commerce, McKay argued that excessive caution and lengthy approval processes are stifling growth and discouraging investment — particularly in major infrastructure and energy projects. “Time costs money. Uncertainty costs money,” he said, urging Canada to “get out of our own way” and move forward with confidence. For financial professionals and advisors, this message underscores a broader challenge: navigating uncertainty while still moving boldly toward opportunity. As markets evolve and policies shift, those who adapt, innovate, and act decisively will lead the next chapter of Canada’s economic story. * [Brian Swanson](https://uk.linkedin.com/in/brian-swansonma?trk=public_post_feed-actor-name)

  Military Veteran | Helping IFA Owners Maximise Exit Value | End-to-End M&A Consultant | Practitioner Experience | Preparing Firms for the 2026 Consolidation Wave | £500M+ Transactions Delivered

  + [Report this post](/uas/login?session_redirect=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.linkedin.com%2Fposts%2Fbrian-swansonma_theres-been-a-lot-of-talk-recently-about-activity-7379417378054361088-gHi9&trk=public_post_ellipsis-menu-semaphore-sign-in-redirect&guestReportContentType=POST&_f=guest-reporting)

  There’s been a lot of talk recently about entrepreneurs and high-net-worth individuals leaving the UK. Are you considering a move abroad? Having spent 14 years as an expat in Eastern Europe, and the Middle East, I can tell you this: getting your finances in order before you go is non-negotiable. When I first moved, I quickly realised that understanding the cost of living wasn’t just useful — it was essential. Without it, you’re flying blind. From groceries to housing, knowing what to expect helps you set a realistic budget and avoid unpleasant surprises. It’s not just about the day-to-day though. Think about the initial costs: flights, shipping belongings, temporary accommodation, even school fees if you have children. These add up fast, and without a plan they can derail your cash flow. I always advise having a financial safety net in place — a buffer for emergencies. It’s that cushion that gives you peace of mind while you get established in a new environment. And don’t forget the obligations you leave behind in the UK. Mortgages, tax, investments — they don’t disappear just because you change time zones. Having a clear strategy for managing these commitments while you’re away makes life a lot easier. Whether you’re relocating for lifestyle, business, or opportunity, the principle is the same: the more clarity and structure you bring to your finances, the smoother your transition will be.

  This timely Globe and Mail opinion piece by financial manager Gideon Hayden discusses the decline of entrepreneurship in Canada and what can be done to ameliorate this alarming trend. Over time, Canada has been creating fewer of the world's high potential start-up firms, falling hugely behind the U.S. on this key metric on a population-adjusted basis. More troubling is research done by Hayden's firm showing that half of Canadian business founders who raised more than $1 million in equity capital in 2024 "were headquartered in the U.S." Canada needs a policy re-set to improve the domestic environment for entrepreneurial wealth creation and business growth. Absent that, there will be no hope of arresting the country's increasingly visible economic decline.

  Sarah's manufacturing company had a great year revenue up 15% but when December arrived, the profits had vanished. Sound familiar? 📊 𝗧𝗵𝗲 𝗛𝗮𝗿𝗱 𝗥𝗲𝗮𝗹𝗶𝘁𝘆: 21.5% of Canadian small businesses fail within their first year 33% say cash flow is their biggest challenge Canada's GDP contracted -0.4% in Q2 2025 29% of business failures are purely from running out of cash But here's where the story gets interesting... 🔄 𝗧𝗵𝗲 𝗚𝗮𝗺𝗲 𝗖𝗵𝗮𝗻𝗴𝗲𝗿: On September 17, 2025, the Bank of Canada is widely expected to cut rates from 2.75% to 2.50% with 25 of 32 economists in Reuters' latest poll predicting this move. Most expect further cuts to 2.25% by December. This creates two distinct paths for Canadian businesses: 😟 𝗣𝗮𝘁𝗵 𝟭: 𝗧𝗵𝗲 𝗦𝘁𝗿𝘂𝗴𝗴𝗹𝗲𝗿𝘀 React to problems as they arise Cut costs without strategy Hope things improve Result: Join the 48% who don't survive 5 years 📈 𝗣𝗮𝘁𝗵 𝟮: 𝗧𝗵𝗲 𝗕𝘂𝗶𝗹𝗱𝗲𝗿𝘀 Sarah chose this path. Here's what she actually did: Shifted to local suppliers (reduced trade risk by 40%) Invested in automation using lower financing costs Built 6-month cash reserves (vs. industry average of 2 months) Diversified beyond her largest customer (from 60% to 35% dependency) The Result: 28% profit increase in 6 months while competitors struggled. 💡 𝗧𝗵𝗲 𝗦𝘁𝗿𝗮𝘁𝗲𝗴𝗶𝗰 𝗜𝗻𝘀𝗶𝗴𝗵𝘁: Economic uncertainty isn't the enemy it's the opportunity. While 71% of Canadian SMBs fail due to management issues, the builders use economic shifts to gain market share, secure better suppliers, and attract top talent from struggling competitors. 𝑇ℎ𝑒 𝑞𝑢𝑒𝑠𝑡𝑖𝑜𝑛 𝑖𝑠𝑛'𝑡 𝑤ℎ𝑒𝑡ℎ𝑒𝑟 𝑒𝑐𝑜𝑛𝑜𝑚𝑖𝑐 𝑐ℎ𝑎𝑙𝑙𝑒𝑛𝑔𝑒𝑠 𝑤𝑖𝑙𝑙 𝑐𝑜𝑛𝑡𝑖𝑛𝑢𝑒 𝑖𝑡'𝑠 𝑤ℎ𝑒𝑡ℎ𝑒𝑟 𝑦𝑜𝑢𝑟 𝑏𝑢𝑠𝑖𝑛𝑒𝑠𝑠 𝑤𝑖𝑙𝑙 𝑝𝑟𝑜𝑓𝑖𝑡 𝑓𝑟𝑜𝑚 𝑡ℎ𝑒𝑚. Every economic shift creates winners and losers. The difference? Strategic financial planning that turns headwinds into competitive advantages. 𝑾𝒉𝒂𝒕 𝒑𝒂𝒕𝒉 𝒊𝒔 𝒚𝒐𝒖𝒓 𝒃𝒖𝒔𝒊𝒏𝒆𝒔𝒔 𝒐𝒏? results.content:
Michael Noble
Chef/Proprietor at The Nash Restaurant & Off Cut Bar
Calgary, Alberta, Canada
500 connections, 894 followers


About
I've worked in all aspects of the culinary profession, from small restaurants to large chains, large and small hotels and also have done a number of consulting jobs either opening new restaurant concepts or overhauling existing ones. My strengths aside from a depth of culinary experience are with people, giving them the knowlege and tools to succeed. I've made a legacy in my career of all the great people who have worked with me and who have gone on to create amazing success for themselves in their own careers. Specialties: NOtaBLE ~ The Restaurant is a full service restaurant which opened in August of 2010. The style of cuisine is "Gourmet Comfort", everything is made in our open kitchen which features a large wood and charcoal burning rotisserie on which you will find succulent aromatic rubbed chickens and a roast feature on every day.


Experience
Chef/Proprietor
[The Nash Restaurant & Off Cut Bar](N/A)  
Nov 2014 - Present
Calgary, Alberta, Canada
My legacy project, combining everything that I've learned in 35+ years in the restaurant industry.This beauty is housed in the former National Hotel, which was opened in July of 1907. The former hotel sat empty for a number of years until I joined forces with interior designer Sarah Ward of Sarah Ward Interiors to create this beautiful room which honours the many decades of history in the neighbourhood of Inglewood. The restaurant consists of the light, airy main dining room which faces into the open kitchen and rotisserie bar and which does a modern take on comforting and satisfying dishes, served in a crisp yet friendly way. The restaurant space includes Off Cut Bar - the somewhat badass, sexy, sultry and yet extremely welcoming area which serves contemporary and classic cocktails along with craft beers, great wines and a menu featuring all secondary cuts of meat, poultry and seafood.One hundred and fifty seats in all, including interesting seating areas and tables made from recovered Canadian prairie barn wood and featuring two community tables situated directly beside the kitchen.


Education
Vancouver Community College
CCFCC Red Seal, Culinary
1979 - 1980
None

results.title: Restaurant Brands International: Jobs
results.content:
Overview:
Restaurant Brands International Inc. is one of the world's largest quick service restaurant companies with nearly $45 billion in annual system-wide sales and over 32,000 restaurants in more than 120 countries and territories. RBI owns four of the world's most prominent and iconic quick service restaurant brands – TIM HORTONS®, BURGER KING®, POPEYES®, and FIREHOUSE SUBS®. These independently operated brands have been serving their respective guests, franchisees and communities for decades. Through its Restaurant Brands for Good framework, RBI is improving sustainable outcomes related to its food, the planet, and people and communities.

Website: https://www.rbi.com/
Crunchbase Url: https://www.crunchbase.com/organization/restaurant-brands-international?utm_source=linkedin&utm_medium=referral&utm_campaign=linkedin_companies&utm_content=profile_cta_anon&trk=funding_crunchbase

results.raw_content:
# Restaurant Brands International
Tim Hortons | Burger King | Popeyes | Firehouse Subs
Food and Beverage Services • Toronto, Ontario • 195,481 followers • 5,001-10,000 employees

## Overview
Restaurant Brands International Inc. is one of the world's largest quick service restaurant companies with nearly $45 billion in annual system-wide sales and over 32,000 restaurants in more than 120 countries and territories. RBI owns four of the world's most prominent and iconic quick service restaurant brands – TIM HORTONS®, BURGER KING®, POPEYES®, and FIREHOUSE SUBS®. These independently operated brands have been serving their respective guests, franchisees and communities for decades. Through its Restaurant Brands for Good framework, RBI is improving sustainable outcomes related to its food, the planet, and people and communities.

### Website
